content.description: This is essentially the downclimb for this boulder. Start sitting on the far right on the back side of the boulder. Climb up tending slightly to the left.
Start sitting on the back side of the Elephant Boulder in the middle of the face about 4 feet to the left of Weekend Warrior. Climb straight up.

Sit start on the arete right next to the trail with a right hand pinch and a left on a sloper around the arete. Pull your ass off the dirt and climb the short arete making use of a cool, vertical pinch/crimp hold in the middle.
content.location: This problem is on the Triangle Boulder. If you are looking at problem Natural Selection on the Elephant Boulder, look to your left and you will see this short 8 footer. This problem climbs the arete closest to the trail.

content.description: Stand/crouch start under the steep, undercut bulge with a huge righthand pinch and a lefthand sloper on the arete. Get a heelhook and slap your way up with some different holds to choose from.
content.location: Directly right and around the corner from Slam Dunk, on the Balanced Boulder.

content.description: Sit start with a big left hand pinch, a right hand gaston, and a good left foot. Crank up to the seam up and right and follow the arete rightwards with good feet to get the slam dunk jug, and top out over the peak.
content.location: This problem is on the Blanced Boulder, which is right next to the Elephant Boulder. If you are looking at the steepest face of the Elephant Boulder, this egg is perched up on a little slab behind it and to the left. This problem climbs the short arete on its backside.

content.description: Start sitting on back side of the Elephant Boulder on the left side near a tree. Climb the faint left arete to the top.

Start sitting matched on a unique, winged-shaped crimp bar in the small cave and do a low traverse right about 6-7 feet using the crack and slots and then make a blind move around the corner battling the barn door and continue up the rising, slopey arete on marginal holds and feet. Set up and slap your right hand out to the obvious blocky side pull on the face. Keep slapping your left hand up the arete and top out over the peak.Grade is for the original extended start described above. Â Grade can range pretty much dependent upon height/reach. Shorter climbers will find it to be harder while taller climbers may find it easier. Perhaps once more feedback comes in we can do a slash grade. Regardless of the grade, just enjoy the movement.

Start sitting roughly in the middle of the sheer face with a high, left hand crimp and a low, right hand, pinchy hold. Pop right hand to a small crimp, lockoff, and get your left hand into the slot. Crank to a pinchy, crimp feature on the arete and then make a cool move to a big sloper higher on the arete. Continue up the arete with difficulty and top out at the peak.

Sit start in an elevator-door on a small, right hand, horizontal crimp and a left hand, vertical gaston. Make a long move left to the arete (there is a small intermediate to help). Adjust and finish up through the crux of Natural Selection.
content.location: It is in the middle of the slightly overhung face. The left hand start is the often used right hand sidepull on Natural Selection.

content.description: Start sitting low with jugs, then move into more jugs up and right, then top it out. This is a nice warm up.
content.location: On the Triangle Boulder, this problem is about 6-7 feet right and around the corner from Triangulation.

content.description: The Elephant Boulder is a 13 foot high, gray, granite beauty. The real attractions are the hard left and right aretes, but it also has a few easier problems, too. This boulder is great in the summer as it gets very little sun.
